text: <@U167FL70V>:  Any suggestions on how to learn about programming concepts in general? Or do you mean just sit down & focus on one, regardless of what it is to start?
Also the movement on this is lovely: <http://codepen.io/VictorBelozyorov/pen/yOBYYv>

attachments.title: Balls of Jelly
attachments.text: This Pure CSS web-animation - Balls of Jelly....

text: pick something that interests you and you will keep up with learning. If something is fascinating or fun its much higher chance of sticking around mentally and higher chance of  follow through. I used to code games, they teach a ton of concepts. and a lot about the language you are using. And they would be fun and engaging

If you have an iPad, I’ve been playing with their Swift Playground app with my kids.  It starts at the most basic level, but is fun and you can skip ahead to wherever you want to work.  It’s a work in progress, but not just a toy
I don’t personally own an iPad, but do we have one in the office I can play with?
It needs to be iOS 10 which is in public beta, but maybe someone will upgrade an office one.  When I get back into the office I can show you it

I would just echo what peter and adrian are saying. it’s super important to make sure you are having fun with it, and to give yourself time to learn by doing. A lot of programming concepts seem really abstract (and dry) when explained on paper, but once you get in there and mess around with code and *see* the results everything clicks
